EDIT: The game went into alpha recently. Most of the points made in my review still apply, but I will no longer be playing this game due to optimization issues.

So im almost at the 500 hour mark... time for a real steam review.

Homebrew Vehicle Sandbox is exactly what it says on the tin. There is one large map populated with several islands that you can roam around in, and there is also a garage where you can create literally any kind of vehicle you can imagine. Their is no questline or story (as of yet), just exploring the map with wacky vehicles and your buddies on the many multiplayer servers available.

+The only limit to what you can build is yourself. Build planes, jets, boats, hot air balloons, tanks, jet-powered flying shlongs. You name it, it can be built.

+Easy building interface. The building mechanics are a cross between voxel-based and components-based, with 'pipes' acting as frame pieces which specialized components can be attached to.

+Incredibly realistic physics engine. Aerodynamics plays a massive part in air vehicles, and at least a basic understanding of real-life physics is needed to make more complicated vehicles.

+Playerbase is incredibly nice and helpful. The devs are very communicative and can often be found playing on their own servers, where you can then bombard them with questions and reccomendations for the game.

+Online multiplayer. Once you're done exploring the map, you can join an online party" and blast people out of the air with hellfire missiles >:D

First and foremost, it needs to be said that this game is in very early stages of development. Additionally, if you don't enjoy things like geometry, physics, engineering, aerodynamics, etc, this  game may not be up your alley.

THAT SAID, I personally find this game extraordinarily brilliant.

There is a learning curve, absolutely, but the complaints that there is no information available to guide you are blatantly false. Granted, it isn't the typical bright and friendly hold-your-hand walkthrough sort of tutorial that lots of full release games have nowadays. People who are capable of reading and following directions will have no trouble, though.

As an avid, lifelong fan of all means of transportation, Homebrew has allowed me to create functional versions of daydream vehicles once confined to the realm of doodles on scratch paper.

There has never been a game quite like this one, and it only stands to improve as time goes on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update Dev 2015: The v14 patch is here! This is a big one. The devs basically remade the game in Unity 5. Some of the systems are entirely re-done and it is overall a big improvement. I'll highlight a few great points below, but this isn't an exhaustive list of all the great changes / addition.

+ much more flexible building tools (like being able to adjust pipes _after_ welding them to your vehicle, etc).

+ you can save vehicles / sub-assemblies and spawn / weld them in other projects :)

+ flexible plating / skin system: It's only the start right now but there are already some easy to use parts for making body panels that far surpass the rigid old dog plates from v13.

+ support for the most wanted thing in this game: servos! Actuators, servo motors, whatever you want to call them. Finally it is very easy to make all manner of things from turrets and landing gear, to swept wings and shuttle bay doors!

+ Great kismet / wiring system. Most of the parts input and/or output (as required) float numbers (generally normalized between -1 and 1) for their functions. You can link inputs and outputs as you want, and there are a variety of modifier parts for combining / shifting / gating / etc the values as you go along. This makes it possible to do things like have a gyrosensor used to adjust the flaps on your plane to keep it level, while still combining it with the input from the user's seat.

+ better physics. I suppose that matters. Center of mass / lift calculated in much better fashion now. It means if you make something that looks like it should fly, it probably will ^___^

+ waves on da ocean

----------------------------------------------

Update Jan 2015: The devs removed the orbs a few patches ago, and now it is a proper sandbox mode (once you complete the initial tutorial). Now you can unleash your creative potential almost immediately!  It is much better this way.

As the game stands now there are lots of things to play with in terms of vehicle parts, and the devs have a lot of cool things in the pipeline too. It's damn fun. Looking forward to future updates :)


Pre-update review: This game would be great if you didn't have to go about collecting annoying little orbs to unlock parts. For a game advertising extensive freedom that seems like an unnecessary and arbitrary restriction, especially for a pre-alpha or whatever it is.

Is this game one I would recommend? Yes. Are there some problems with it? Of course, it's still an early access title. It's much more optimized, so it can definitely be played on some slightly lower end PCs. I use my Xbox 360 controller for vehicles, which makes things a bit easier on me. You have lots of options as to what to build (and there is still more to come). I've built everything from small 110cc powered boats to hypersonic jets that can go past 7,400 km/h before hitting the world border (took me 3 days of continuous testing and improvement.

The one thing people don't get about physics and this game is that this is not something you'd find in Forza, NFS, GTA or CoD. This is all about solid and fluid dynamics. It's about what you can do to improve the quality of whatever you build. Build it faster, stronger, more efficient. This is something that takes practice, not something you can just pick up and go. But, once you do get the hang of it the possibilities are nearly endless. I just hope they make longer runways and bigger worlds. My hypersonic jet can go much faster than 7.4k km/h.

Another Sandbox Vehicle game, But wait.... this might be different,
Homebrew opens the mind up to a few more challenges than usual and even offers a multiplayer that we haven't seen in many sandbox vehicle games besides those stricly with PvP. When you spawn into the world for the first time you might be amazed with how much stuff there is to do, and plans for more and much bigger maps are in the works, so you can expect to have a fair bit of exploring to do. From quarter pipes to insane ramps launching you over waterfalls, you'll have a fun time doing stunts and flipping your vehicle all over the place.
There is a vehicle editor that allows you to build your own creations. The building system is a little difficult to master at first but once you figure it out, building your own rides is actually the best part of the game. Pit them up against your friends on a racetrak or go for the most airtime on a quarter pipe with your rocket powered dragster.  Sharing will be made available to upload and share your creations with your friends and others, I'm not sure if this is going to be via Steam Workshop or not but sharing is planned for the future.
There is a story line planned as well which could add a lot more playability to the game in the future, could we even possibly see a coop mode?
As of now, it's still a little buggy at times but the future of Homebrew is looking really good. If you like creating and building, I suggest you pick this up when you get a chance. Just remember, It is in early access.

So Homebrew.  Lets see, where to start?  Is the game good?  yes.  Am I good with reveiws?  Absolutely not.  But how else are you gonna know it is good unless people tell you it is.  Whether or not they're good at telling you it is good.  But enough of that, on to the actual reveiw I guess.

So yeah.  Homebrew...  Obviously this isn't game about brewing moonshine in your back yard over a can of beer.  Which is kinda pointless, since you're drinking other alchohal that you payed for while making alchohal that you sell to pay for buying other alchohol, so WTF.  Anyway, we're not doing any of that in Homebrew.  In Homebrew Vehicle Sandbox, you're making your own vehicles and enjoying created vehicles within a sandbox environment.  So sorry all you moonshiners, but this is not a game about making moonshine.  Instead, Homebrew is about embracing creativity, in whatever form that may come in, and making vehicles with it.  Be it cars, trucks, planes, boats, airships, helicopters, Gundams (though I haven't seen any gundams yet.  Someone get on this, please), trains, hoverbikes, rockets, etc.  You name it and, with enough creativity and the right know-how, you can make it.

Homebrew does this by offering an expansive vehicle builder allowing you to combine all kinds of parts to make whatever you want.  Including a unique take on logic systems that most other vehicle building games simply don't offer.  Certainly not Space Engineers.

Homebrew really has somethign in it for everyone.  If you like a certain car a lot, you can replicate it in Homebrew.  If you've got some crazy idea for a plane, you can build it in Homebrew and enjoy all that wackiness from the safety of your living room.  If you're an artist, Homebrew certainly isn't any kind of sculptign or painting software.  However, you can still make brilliant artwark by using it.

Not to speak lightly of it by making it my third point, but Homebrew also has amazing developers and community.  If  you're having trouble with anything related to the game, or even things not related to the game, shoot the community a question and you'll get a friendly answer fairly soon.  And if not, the devs themselves will usually come help you out!  How awesome is that?

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis one has grabbed me. It's not so much a game as a great kit for building things and trying them out in an expansive world. In fact, it's the closest thing I've found to an actual sandbox game. On the upside, the tools are easy to use and there are enough parts at this point to build a wide range of wacky contraptions. The world is simple, but it's attractive enough to enjoy, and it provides a good sense of space and motion as you invariably crash into it - repeatedly. The physics are solid and flexible enough to give you feedback on your design choices, but on the downside, they aren't realistic feeling. Just like any driving/flying game, it's a compromise. Once you stop trying to make it behave like the real world, it turns into a lot of fun. I'm experiencing some graphical flickering here and there, but I'm sure that will get straightened out. The devs are actively updating and involved in the forum discussions. There is no free build mode. You have to gather orbs to pay for parts, but it's easy enough to get a full kit of parts pretty quickly. There is apparently a way to get around the orb gathering, but I'm not smart enough to figure out the hints on the forums and I got tired of standing around in the pyramid with a dumb look on my face. :) Anyway, if you like to build and test and basically fiddle around with mechanical systems, this game will keep you entertained for many hours.

Probably my first very in-depth review:
Updated 11/19/14

This game is exactly what Minecraft, Terraria, Starbound, Starmade, Space Engineers, all of those games can't be. Even with their fancy mods and workshop items. This game is a sandbox that goes down to the pipe, to the engine, to the little motor you wouldn't think to place in a plane. It's exactly what it says on the box:
Step 1, Make object.
Step 2: Fly/drive/boat (soon)/etc object,
Step 3: ????
Step 4: Profit may vary.

As a bonus, there a sort of free roam aspect to the game where you can roam around as an actual living human being instead of just an entity that inhabits the menu system. Along with that, I downloaded this getting something I didn't even expect to get: Multiplayer. I don't know how it works yet since I haven't forced this game onto a friend, but that'll change.

As of this review, there've been many updates over these past seven days alone. A good sign that this is constantly being worked on.

On the downside,however, this game is still taking some getting used to even now, and the controller settings really aren't optimal yet. And it's not really just the controller, but the keyboard controls sometimes either don't work, or are just weird. There's a TON of Engrish in just about every bit of dialogue (while it doesn't hinder gameplay, it does hinder game quality), and do I even lift? (An engine? Into a freaking plane without glitching the wing into the other one and forcing a tail fin onto the ground without breaking it off?).

Finally, the price tag as of this moment is probably not worth it if you're into waiting for Steam Sales only to buy all of your games. Maybe at a later date when issues are fixed and a lot of things are added, sure, but until then, maybe $9.99 USD.

Despite all of the bad, I still recommend it if you want more detail out of your building time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One thing before I start is that I want to say that this game is in development by a very small team, a very dedicated and easy to talk to, but very small.

That being said, those of you not familiar with the early access process should probably have taken the time to read a little bit about it before buying this game.  I have purchased many early access games on steam and while I wouldn't mind it if games had to be a bit better before being released to the public, I still enjoyed the process of just about every game I became a part of.  Some early access games I have been apart of took years to get to a playable state.  Maybe I'm just too patient.

Now on to the review!

As others have said, this is a sandbox building game where you can connect various pieces to make various things to drive and fly around a fairly large game area.  The build system, while a bit tricky at first, is surprisingly flexible and for those of you who know gmod/source welds, it is refreshing in how rigid the various components are and how easy it is to lift the hood and really customize things from gear ratios to fuel tank sizes.

At this point in development, there are few different components ranging from small gasoline engines to vectored thrust jet engines plus all the necessary connectors and logic components needed to make them do what you want with them.  A huge selling point here is that it is not a voxel based assembly system but rather more like legos where some of the legos come in different sizes and you can even bend them to meet the way you want them to.

Once you bring your creations into the world they behave more or less how you would expect them to.  The physics need work but they are quite usable and in a lot of cases the developers took the time to really get things right rather than cheating" like some other games do when it comes to the calculations behind the scenes.

I personally like making 6 wheeled monster trucks to drive on a tight cliff track or to try to optimize my propeller on my small scout plane so that it rotates just shy of the speed of sound to keep it at optimum efficiency.

Having followed the forums a little bit
date: I can see that there will be some upcoming updates to physics _and_ multiplayer which is quite exciting as I can't wait to race my solar powered cars around a huge oval track or try to find and shoot down other planes that encroach on my building area.  I won't use the word potential here because you really never know
recommended: but from what I see as an armchair designer/engineer
hoursPlayed: I can't wait.\n\nIn conclusion:  Don't buy this if you don't want to be in an alpha test of a physics sandbox game that changes a lot for the better.  There are other games out there in a high level of development that will satisfy your desires better...but I can say I have never found a game like this that quite captures what it is I love to do-design and test vehicles in a varied and interesting environment.  Sprinkle in some multiplayer and some exciting new parts and you're looking at an excellent addition to the world of sandbox games."

Alright. This will be my first review I believe.

First off, I'm not that drawn to alpha/pre-alpha games. I've gone broke on previous alpha games in the past. But this game, this game is different.

Ever had an idea for a great vehicle?  Ever wanted to spend hours designing it - tweaking every joint until it was perfect?  Ever wanted to feel the satisfaction of the physics engine realizing your genius and completely submitting to this amazing design?

If so, move along.  This game is a dreamshatterer - in a way.  I have so many ideas for vehicles and I can build them in a few hours, but that is just the beginnng.  After it is built, you still have real world physics to deal with.  Take KSP, throw in tons more customizations, and of course remove the whole space thing (for now?), and you have this game.  ;)

My only complaint is a minor one.  The world is really small.  I finally built a jet that could get up to 4500km/h, but I hit the end of the world before it reaches its full potential.  When this happens, you just pop back up at the garage.  It is a minor complaint, because I am sure the world will be vast and much more populated (with challenges - like inside the arena area).  And yes, it has sonic booms.

Small issues aside it's great. Once it gets weapons, it will be the best and most powerful vehicle builder there is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun vehicle building game with multiplayer mechanics and a powerful method of building which can be used to create anything you can think of. There are weapons and enemies to use them against but I don't want to spoil too much. You can obviously fight other players in your vehicles which is good fun, and since the devs have an armour plating system planned, thats gonna get really interesting.

There is a varied map with roads, a swamp, large bodies of water, mountains and sand - so you can test your vehicle offline or with friends on a variety of surfaces/environments. The map hides lots of secrets, I haven't found them all and the community is still trying to figure out a few of the more enigmatic ones.

People seem to be complaining that it is difficult to use, I have to say I wouldn't agree. I have nearly 42 hours on record at the time of writing this plus more before it was on steam. At hour 42+ I'm obviously a much better builder than I was at hour 0, but even at the start the system seemed intuitive and anything I didn't understand was cleared up by tutorials or help from the amazing community and dev support on the website.

It's in alpha yes, and I am apprehensive about buying games in alpha sometimes but not with this one. There are bugs present as with all alphas, but there are no major gamebreakers. There has been regular updates and the devs are literally in constant communication with the players, and I know if I had a pressing issue with the game or needed help with mechanics of the game I'd be able to get it faster than pretty much any of the other games in my library, plus the community are always happy to help on the chat on the homebrew website or the group chat on steam.

Overall a really good sandbox vehicle builder with massive potential that is going in the right direction. I'd reccomend it, just take half an hour to learn the building system at the start using tutorials (like you have to do with all other sandbox building games like KSP etc) and you'll have a blast.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Homebrew is exactly as the title states, a vehicle sandbox game.  You create your own vehicles from scratch, frame, gas tank and all, and then take them into the medium size sandbox world surrounding the garage area you created the vehicle in.  You can design and craft anything from go-karts, golf carts, 4-wheelers, cars, dragsters, tanks, motorbikes, planes, helicopters, hovercrafts and more.

There is a really extensive crafting system in this game, although I feel the tutorial and instruction set is lacking and the overall crafting system feels a bit cluttered, very unrefined, and generally clunky and lazily put-together.  There is multiplayer, which is a nice touch, but really doesn't fix any of the problems with the game itself.

The vehicle controls are clunky and weird, making many of the vehicles hard to control, and the fact that the physics system in the game is very odd certainly doesn't do this problem any favors.  Also, not that a game like this should be about graphics, but the developers have obviously tried to bring something at least mildly modern-looking to the table, but last I saw, they have failed terribly.  The games graphics look like the industry standard as of 2006, and for a game that tries to have decent graphics, I consider this a failure.

All-in-all, I do not recommend this game in its current state.  The graphics are outdated and poorly designed.  The physics is quirky, which compounds the issue that the controls are touchy, buggy and generally difficult to use, and the crafting system is really unrefined and includes part names like pipe_001, pipe_002, curvepipe_001 and so on.  The whole game seems like it's just way too early in development for any kind of early access release.  I have hope that the developers can improve upon the games issues, but until then, I will advise people to not make this purchase.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW ( 19 Dec. 2014)
tldr: Wait for a better version before investing.
I agree with this guy: http://steamcommunity.com/app/325420/discussions/0/626329820885200239/

There have been some updates, which i haven't experienced from play, but just based on writing they seem to be really good.
It also seem to be quite the alpha version, with a fair deal of ability to change the game design, but also a fair deal of doubt in how it will turn out to be.

My experience however is that most games tend to be feature complete while in EA. It doesn't seem to be the case here, so there might be changes to all the downsides i consider for this game.

1. Physics:
While this game tries to cover water, land and air at the same time, i don't expect a overhelming great physics in each part, as in a simulator. However there are some parts to the physic that i consider too flawish for a game like this. Mainly how breaking and a reverse vector applied to the resulting vector seems lacking.
Also using a handbrake on a slope, should not give you more speed....

When it comes to flying, it is quite clear that you need to consider how you balance the weight is important. That is a plus, but unfortunately some of the engines seems to be a bit extreme and will put you in a loop regardless of your controls.

2. Game loop is too simple.  (build -> test)*
While The game is indeed all about building and testing, it just seems like the testing aspect could use some sub-loops to create some kind of challenge or a feeling of achivement.
While removing the orbs, from what i read and would determine myself, was a really good idea. Perhaps there could be some challenges which could unlock some non essential, or bonus like content.

This is one of the things i hope will be improved in the future.

These issues are the ones feel is most worth mentioning, as they make the game feel incomplete or borken.
The constructing part is really good and interesting, so if those issues aren't important to you, then it is worth giving it a go, especially if you can get the game at discount.
There are a chance that these will be improved, but it depends on how far the development is at the current stage. Hence I suggest people to wait a bit and see if these parts get any changes to the better.

Early Access Review

I had a few issues with this game when I first started, this is why I gave it the thumbs down (for now)!

You can eventually work your way through the tute (not easy as they don't explain things very well), but after that it says to go out side and take the vehicle for a ride.

Problem is, you have to actually go up to a console inside the garage, (no idea why the vehicles are not inside the garage) and tell it you want to go outside, once outside, there is no vehicle, you have to press i to get a list of vehicles, then press i again to stop displaying the list of available vehicles, then point up in the air and press left mouse button to throw the vehicle in the air (again, no idea why you would do this), and then chase the vehicle as it will most likely start rolling away, no hand brake. Once you finally get a vehicle (remember to press x to start the motor), it is very hard to control it, there does not appear to be a button to press for brake, also it says to press page up and page down to zoom in and out, nothing happens. Not being able to zoom out a little makes it hard to see where your going. Editing vehicles is a little daunting at first, being unsure which parts fit with what, the tute vehicle requires a motor (when putting this in, it would be handy if the default angle of the motor would be suitable to put it in with out having to rotate it first), which I gave it, but when I went out side, it did not have a motor or even a left front wheel. Going to quick edit, it had a motor so you can not give it another, it also had all of the wheels, then switching to tune it had no motor or wheel (wtf). They could make this game a little more user friendly. Maybe add to the tute a highlighting function that lets you know where to place the parts that it is telling you to install!

Controlling the ground vehicles is very hard, because the camera is doining its own thing, so not controllable by the user. Most of the time is will go behind the vehicle, so long as you are going in a straight line, so it is not too bad. What is bad, is that the angle of the camera is not high enough off the ground behind the vehicle, so you will have trouble seeing where you are going when going over hills. It would be much better to provide an option for the user to have some controll over the camera.

Controlling the vehicle is also rather hard, especially at speed, it has major oversteer problems at speed, as well as the camera problem already mentioned, of not seeing where your going when going over hills.

There does not seem to be much to do while driving, collecting objects and going over ramps. I have not progressed to air travel at this time, so don't know what there is to do up in the sky.

At present they need to make it more user friendly, they are actively working on it and answering comments left here so I remain hopeful that this will end up being a really good game!!!

This game is good, but still, it has plenty of room to develop. Of course, building a vehicle is hard if you just started to play the game, but in 5-6 hours you can get a good grip. Thus, with that said, controls are a bit quirky. Sure, it is still at dev stage, and I am really amused by it, but you will have a little hard time getting around things because they are a little bit irregular. There is no objectives as far as I can see, so this game is a good companion for those who love open-world games like minecraft and terraria.

If this stage was the last stage of the game, I'd rate it as 6/10. Altrough it is still alpha, so in this case, I really believe that this game has the potential to be 10/10.

I just wish that we can create our own systems for auto control, and develop some stuff. This goes to developers : Think of a on-board computer that you can adjust your outputs accordingly to your imputs. What will it do? For example, You want your thruster to be activated only if you are above 20kmh. Maybe gradually increasing thrust to avoid the vehicle to flip. Which language? Lua would be ok, since it has been used on ComputerCraft in Tekkit, Minecraft, and it is indeed easy to learn. Maybe python or ruby would be good as well.

The thing that I requested is pretty complicated indeed, but if it could be done, this game would be skyrocketing trough other simulation types. Think about you can program like a plane autopilot or something. Wow.

10/10 for a game that is in alpha. Good job devs.

I like the Idea, but this game has a long way to go before I would consider buying it again (got a refund). If the graphics and vehicle mechanics don't matter alot to you, I would say go for it. Otherwise, there's BeamNG and Autocraft...

Part A does this.
Part B does that.
Part C does something different.
Part Z helps you work parts A-Y.

So.......Is there enough parts? Nope. There can never be enough parts.

USE ALL THE PARTS!!!!!!!!
(5 hours later)
us-use...all....the parts? *mentally breaking down*

(2 days later)
OooOoo. New workshop upload.
(Thus the building cycle restarts.)


All and all, it's a fun and interesting game. But this is a title that will not appeal to everyone. With the current version of the game, the building is fairly in depth and some of the parts are tricky to use. Yet, more parts are coming to the list. Which means wilder creations. The limit is your own creativity and what you can figure out. Tho there are people in the community willing to give a helping hand/tips if you need it. Visuals look good but there are still a few bugs the devs are working on getting fixed. For me that doesn't affect me, or my creations.

A solid game about building vehicles and having fun with them.
